docs.title: Your Cross-Platform Stack Manager
docs.text:
Machineconfig is a swiss-army knife CLI tool — a Package Manager, Configuration Manager, Automation Tool, Dotfiles Manager, Data Solution, and Code Manager, all rolled into one seamless cross-platform experience.

Get Started View on GitHub

docs.title: Why Machineconfig?
docs.text:
Setting up a new machine, VM, or Docker container often involves navigating complex dependency chains:

flowchart TD
    A["Need to setup my dev environment"] --> B["Need tool X (e.g., yadm)"]
    B --> C["Requires git"]
    C --> D["Requires package manager (e.g., brew)"]
    D --> E["Requires curl"]
    E --> F["Requires network setup / system update"]
    F --> G["Requires system configuration access"]
    G --> H["Finally ready to start!"]

Machineconfig eliminates this complexity by providing a unified tool that:

  • Manages packages across all platforms
  • Configures systems automatically
  • Syncs dotfiles seamlessly
  • Handles data backup and sync
  • Automates repetitive tasks

docs.title: Hosting Your Documentation
docs.text: This guide covers all options for hosting MkDocs documentation, from local development to free global hosting.

docs.title: Quick Serve
docs.text:
uv run mkdocs serve

Opens at http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: Custom Port
docs.text: uv run mkdocs serve --dev-addr=0.0.0.0:8080

docs.title: Live Reload (default)
docs.text:
MkDocs automatically reloads when you edit files. To disable:

uv run mkdocs serve --no-livereload

docs.title: Build Static Files
docs.text:
uv run mkdocs build

Creates a site/ directory with static HTML files.

docs.title: 1. GitHub Pages (Recommended)
docs.text:
Best for: Open source projects on GitHub

Pros: - Completely free - Automatic HTTPS - Custom domain support - Direct integration with MkDocs

Setup:

One Command DeployGitHub Actions (Automated) 
uv run mkdocs gh-deploy

This builds and pushes to the gh-pages branch automatically.

Create .github/workflows/docs.yml:

name: Deploy Docs
on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  contents: write

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.13'

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v4

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: uv sync --group dev

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        run: uv run mkdocs gh-deploy --force

Enable GitHub Pages:

  1. Go to repository Settings → Pages
  2. Source: Deploy from a branch
  3. Branch: gh-pages / (root)
  4. Save

Your docs will be at: https://thisismygitrepo.github.io/machineconfig/

docs.title: 2. Cloudflare Pages
docs.text:
Best for: Fast global CDN, unlimited bandwidth

Pros: - Unlimited bandwidth (free tier) - Global CDN (300+ locations) - Automatic HTTPS - Custom domains - Preview deployments for PRs

Setup:

  1. Go to Cloudflare Pages
  2. Connect your GitHub repository
  3. Configure build settings:
Setting Value Build command pip install mkdocs-material mkdocstrings[python] && mkdocs build Build output directory site Root directory /

Or use a build script - create build_docs.sh:

#!/bin/bash
pip install uv
uv sync --group dev
uv run mkdocs build

Then set build command to: bash build_docs.sh

docs.title: 3. Netlify
docs.text:
Best for: Easy setup, good free tier

Pros: - 100GB bandwidth/month (free) - Automatic HTTPS - Custom domains - Deploy previews - Form handling

Setup:

  1. Go to Netlify
  2. Import your GitHub repository
  3. Configure:
Setting Value Build command pip install mkdocs-material mkdocstrings[python] && mkdocs build Publish directory site

Or create netlify.toml:

[build]
  command = "pip install mkdocs-material mkdocstrings[python] mkdocs-autorefs && mkdocs build"
  publish = "site"

[build.environment]
  PYTHON_VERSION = "3.11"

docs.title: 4. Vercel
docs.text:
Best for: Fast deployments, serverless functions

Pros: - Unlimited bandwidth (fair use) - Global edge network - Automatic HTTPS - Preview deployments

Setup:

  1. Go to Vercel
  2. Import repository
  3. Create vercel.json:
{
  "buildCommand": "pip install mkdocs-material mkdocstrings[python] && mkdocs build",
  "outputDirectory": "site",
  "installCommand": "pip install mkdocs"
}

docs.title: 5. GitLab Pages
docs.text:
Best for: GitLab users

Pros: - Free for public/private repos - Automatic HTTPS - CI/CD integration

Setup - create .gitlab-ci.yml:

image: python:3.11

pages:
  stage: deploy
  script:
    - pip install mkdocs-material mkdocstrings[python]
    - mkdocs build --site-dir public
  artifacts:
    paths:
      - public
  only:
    - main

docs.title: 6. Read the Docs
docs.text:
Best for: Python projects, versioned docs

Pros: - Free for open source - Automatic versioning - PDF/ePub generation - Search across versions

Setup:

  1. Go to Read the Docs
  2. Import your repository
  3. Create .readthedocs.yaml:
version: 2

build:
  os: ubuntu-22.04
  tools:
    python: "3.11"

mkdocs:
  configuration: mkdocs.yml

python:
  install:
    - requirements: docs/requirements.txt

Create docs/requirements.txt:

mkdocs>=1.6.0
mkdocs-material>=9.7.0
mkdocstrings[python]>=1.0.0
mkdocs-autorefs>=1.0.0

docs.title: 7. Render
docs.text:
Best for: Simple static hosting

Pros: - 100GB bandwidth/month - Automatic HTTPS - Custom domains

Setup:

  1. Go to Render
  2. New → Static Site
  3. Connect repository
  4. Configure:
Setting Value Build Command pip install mkdocs-material mkdocstrings[python] && mkdocs build Publish Directory site

docs.title: 8. Surge.sh
docs.text:
Best for: Quick CLI deployments

Pros: - Simple CLI - Free custom domains - Unlimited publishing

Setup:

# Install surge
npm install -g surge

# Build docs
uv run mkdocs build

# Deploy
cd site && surge

First time will prompt for email/password. Your docs will be at https://random-name.surge.sh

Custom domain:

surge site/ yourdomain.surge.sh

docs.title: 9. Firebase Hosting
docs.text:
Best for: Google ecosystem users

Pros: - 10GB storage, 360MB/day transfer (free) - Global CDN - Custom domains

Setup:

# Install Firebase CLI
npm install -g firebase-tools

# Login
firebase login

# Initialize
firebase init hosting

# Build docs
uv run mkdocs build

# Deploy
firebase deploy --only hosting

Configure firebase.json:

{
  "hosting": {
    "public": "site",
    "ignore": ["firebase.json", "**/.*", "**/node_modules/**"]
  }
}

docs.text:
Most platforms follow similar steps:

  1. Add domain in platform settings
  2. Configure DNS:

For apex domain (example.com): 

A     @     185.199.108.153  (GitHub Pages IP)
A     @     185.199.109.153
A     @     185.199.110.153
A     @     185.199.111.153

For subdomain (docs.example.com): 

CNAME docs  thisismygitrepo.github.io

  1. Wait for DNS propagation (up to 24 hours)
  2. Enable HTTPS in platform settings

docs.text: UV is a fast Python package installer that handles everything for you.

docs.title: Step 1: Install UV
docs.text:
Linux / macOSWindows 
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"

docs.title: Step 2: Install Machineconfig
docs.text:
uv tool install --upgrade --python 3.14 machineconfig

This installs machineconfig as a global CLI tool with all its commands available immediately.

docs.text:
If you prefer using pip:

pip install machineconfig

Python Version

Machineconfig requires Python 3.13 or higher. Make sure your Python installation meets this requirement.

docs.text:
After installation, verify that machineconfig is working:

mcfg --help

You should see the help output listing all available commands.

cd machineconfig
uv sync --group dev

  • Testing: pytest
  • Linting: ruff, mypy, pyright
  • Documentation: mkdocs, mkdocs-material, mkdocstrings

docs.title: Path Extended
docs.text: Extended path operations and utilities.

docs.title: PathExtended
docs.text:
Bases: type(Path()), Path

The default behaviour of methods acting on underlying disk object is to perform the action and return a new path referring to the mutated object in disk drive. However, there is a flag orig that makes the function return orignal path object self as opposed to the new one pointing to new object. Additionally, the fate of the original object can be decided by a flag inplace which means replace it defaults to False and in essence, it deletes the original underlying object. This can be seen in zip and encrypt but not in copy, move, retitle because the fate of original file is dictated already. Furthermore, those methods are accompanied with print statement explaining what happened to the object.

docs.title: append
docs.text:
append(
    name: str = "",
    index: bool = False,
    suffix: Optional[str] = None,
    verbose: bool = True,
    **kwargs: Any
) -> PathExtended

Returns a new path object with the name appended to the stem of the path. If index is True, the name will be the index of the path in the parent directory.

Source code in src/machineconfig/utils/path_extended.py 
def append(self, name: str = "", index: bool = False, suffix: Optional[str] = None, verbose: bool = True, **kwargs: Any) -> "PathExtended":
    """Returns a new path object with the name appended to the stem of the path. If `index` is True, the name will be the index of the path in the parent directory."""
    if index:
        appended_name = f"""{name}_{len(self.parent.search(f"*{self.name.split('.')[0]}*"))}"""
        return self.append(name=appended_name, index=False, verbose=verbose, suffix=suffix, **kwargs)
    full_name = name or ("_" + str(timestamp()))
    full_suffix = suffix or "".join(("bruh" + self).suffixes)
    subpath = self.name.split(".")[0] + full_name + full_suffix
    dest = self.parent.joinpath(subpath)
    res = PathExtended(dest)
    inplace = bool(kwargs.get("inplace", False))
    overwrite = bool(kwargs.get("overwrite", False))
    orig = bool(kwargs.get("orig", False))
    strict = bool(kwargs.get("strict", True))
    if inplace:
        assert self.exists(), f"`inplace` flag is only relevant if the path exists. It doesn't {self}"
        if overwrite and res.exists():
            res.delete(sure=True, verbose=verbose)
        if not overwrite and res.exists():
            if strict:
                raise FileExistsError(f"❌ RENAMING failed. File `{res}` already exists.")
            else:
                if verbose:
                    try:
                        print(f"⚠️ SKIPPED RENAMING {repr(self)} ➡️ {repr(res)} because FileExistsError and scrict=False policy.")
                    except UnicodeEncodeError:
                        print("P._return warning: UnicodeEncodeError, could not print message.")
                return self if orig else res
        self.rename(res)
        if verbose:
            try:
                print(f"RENAMED {repr(self)} ➡️ {repr(res)}")
            except UnicodeEncodeError:
                print("P._return warning: UnicodeEncodeError, could not print message.")
    return self if orig else res

docs.title: cloud
docs.text: Cloud provider management and data synchronization.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: cloud [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

docs.title: config
docs.text:
Configure cloud storage providers.

cloud config [PROVIDER]

Supported Providers:

  • onedrive - Microsoft OneDrive
  • gdrive - Google Drive
  • dropbox - Dropbox
  • s3 - Amazon S3
  • azure - Azure Blob Storage
  • sftp - SFTP server

docs.title: setup-encrypted
docs.text:
Create an encrypted remote for sensitive data.

cloud setup-encrypted NAME [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --backend Backend remote to encrypt --password Encryption password

docs.title: sync
docs.text:
Synchronize files between locations.

cloud sync SOURCE DESTINATION [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --dry-run Preview without changes --mirror Make destination identical --bidirectional Two-way sync --delete Delete extra files in destination

Examples:

# Sync to cloud
cloud sync ~/documents gdrive:documents

# Mirror a directory
cloud sync --mirror ~/data backup:data

# Preview sync
cloud sync --dry-run ~/important remote:backup

docs.title: backup
docs.text:
Create a backup of local data.

cloud backup PATH [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --destination Backup destination --compress Compress backup --encrypt Encrypt backup

docs.title: restore
docs.text:
Restore data from backup.

cloud restore SOURCE DESTINATION [OPTIONS]

docs.title: list
docs.text:
List files in remote storage.

cloud list REMOTE:PATH

docs.title: list-backups
docs.text:
List available backups.

cloud list-backups [REMOTE]

docs.title: info
docs.text:
Show information about remote storage.

cloud info [REMOTE]

docs.title: schedule-backup
docs.text:
Set up automatic backups.

cloud schedule-backup PATH [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --interval hourly, daily, weekly --destination Backup destination

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Configure OneDrive
cloud config onedrive

# Sync documents
cloud sync ~/documents onedrive:documents

# Create encrypted backup
cloud backup ~/secrets --encrypt --destination encrypted:backup

# Restore from backup
cloud restore onedrive:backup/2024-01-15 ~/restored

# Schedule daily backup
cloud schedule-backup ~/important --interval daily

docs.title: fire
docs.text: Fire-based job execution system.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: fire [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The fire command provides a Python Fire-based interface for executing jobs and functions directly from the command line.

docs.title: Basic Execution
docs.text:
fire run MODULE.FUNCTION [ARGS]

Example:

fire run my_module.my_function --arg1 value1 --arg2 value2

docs.title: With Positional Arguments
docs.text: fire run process_data input.csv output.csv --format json

docs.title: List Available Jobs
docs.text:
fire list [MODULE]

Lists all callable functions in a module.

docs.title: Job Information
docs.text:
fire info MODULE.FUNCTION

Shows function signature, docstring, and parameters.

docs.title: Execution Options
docs.text: Option Description --verbose Show detailed output --dry-run Preview without execution --timeout Set execution timeout --background Run in background

docs.title: Interactive Mode
docs.text:
Start an interactive session:

fire interactive MODULE

This opens a REPL with the module's functions available.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Run a function
fire run my_jobs.cleanup --days 30

# List functions in module
fire list my_jobs

# Get function info
fire info my_jobs.process_data

# Run with timeout
fire run long_task.compute --timeout 3600

# Run in background
fire run backup.full --background

docs.title: Creating Jobs
docs.text:
Jobs are regular Python functions:

# my_jobs.py

def cleanup(days: int = 7, dry_run: bool = False):
    """Clean up old files.

    Args:
        days: Delete files older than this many days
        dry_run: Preview without deleting
    """
    # Implementation
    pass

def process_data(input_file: str, output_file: str, format: str = "csv"):
    """Process data file.

    Args:
        input_file: Path to input file
        output_file: Path to output file
        format: Output format (csv, json, parquet)
    """
    # Implementation
    pass

Then run them:

fire run my_jobs.cleanup --days 14
fire run my_jobs.process_data data.csv result.json --format json

docs.title: sessions
docs.text: Terminal session management for persistent and remote sessions.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: sessions [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

docs.title: list
docs.text:
List all active sessions.

sessions list [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --all Include inactive sessions --json Output as JSON

docs.title: create
docs.text:
Create a new session.

sessions create NAME [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --shell Shell to use --directory Starting directory

docs.title: attach
docs.text:
Attach to an existing session.

sessions attach NAME

docs.title: detach
docs.text:
Detach from current session.

sessions detach

docs.title: kill
docs.text:
Terminate a session.

sessions kill NAME

docs.title: exec
docs.text:
Execute a command on remote targets.

sessions exec "COMMAND" [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --targets Comma-separated list of hosts --parallel Execute in parallel --timeout Command timeout

Example:

sessions exec "hostname && uptime" --targets server1,server2,server3

docs.title: connect
docs.text:
Connect to a remote machine.

sessions connect HOST [OPTIONS]

Options:

Option Description --user SSH username --key SSH key file --port SSH port

docs.title: Session Types
docs.text:
Machineconfig supports multiple session backends:

Backend Description tmux Terminal multiplexer screen GNU Screen zellij Modern terminal workspace

docs.title: Using a Specific Backend
docs.text:
sessions --backend tmux create dev
sessions --backend zellij create dev

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# List all sessions
sessions list

# Create a development session
sessions create dev --directory ~/projects

# Attach to session
sessions attach dev

# Execute on multiple servers
sessions exec "apt update" --targets web1,web2,db1

# Connect to remote
sessions connect myserver --user admin

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text: Guidelines for writing code that fits the Machineconfig codebase.

docs.title: Formatting
docs.text: We use Ruff for formatting and linting.

docs.title: Format Code
docs.text: uv run ruff format src/

docs.title: Check Linting
docs.text: uv run ruff check src/

docs.title: Type Hints
docs.text:
All code should include type hints:

def process_file(path: str, encoding: str = "utf-8") -> list[str]:
    """Process a file and return lines."""
    ...

Run type checking with:

uv run pyright

docs.title: Docstrings
docs.text:
Use Google-style docstrings:

def example_function(param1: str, param2: int) -> bool:
    """Short description of function.

    Longer description if needed, explaining what the function
    does in more detail.

    Args:
        param1: Description of param1.
        param2: Description of param2.

    Returns:
        Description of return value.

    Raises:
        ValueError: When param2 is negative.

    Example:
        >>> example_function("test", 42)
        True
    """
    ...

docs.title: Imports
docs.text:
Organize imports in this order:

  1. Standard library
  2. Third-party packages
  3. Local imports
import os
from pathlib import Path

import rich
from rich.console import Console

from machineconfig.utils import accessories

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text: Type Convention Example Functions snake_case process_file() Variables snake_case file_path Classes PascalCase RemoteMachine Constants UPPER_SNAKE DEFAULT_TIMEOUT Modules snake_case remote_machine.py

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Use specific exceptions and provide helpful messages:

def connect(host: str) -> Connection:
    if not host:
        raise ValueError("Host cannot be empty")

    try:
        return Connection(host)
    except ConnectionError as e:
        raise ConnectionError(f"Failed to connect to {host}: {e}") from e

docs.title: Data Sync
docs.text: Backup and synchronize your data across machines and cloud storage.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Machineconfig integrates with rclone to provide powerful data synchronization capabilities:

  • Sync to cloud storage providers
  • Encrypted backups
  • Incremental syncing
  • Cross-platform support

docs.title: Supported Backends
docs.text: Provider Status OneDrive Full support Google Drive Full support Dropbox Full support AWS S3 Full support Azure Blob Full support SFTP Full support Local Full support

This walks you through setting up your preferred cloud provider.

docs.title: Sync Data
docs.text: cloud sync /local/path remote:path

docs.text: cloud backup /important/data

docs.title: Mirror
docs.text:
One-way sync that makes destination identical to source:

cloud sync --mirror source/ dest/

docs.title: Bidirectional
docs.text:
Two-way sync that merges changes:

cloud sync --bidirectional source/ dest/

docs.title: Encryption
docs.text:
Encrypt sensitive data before uploading:

# Setup encrypted remote
cloud setup-encrypted myencrypted

# Sync to encrypted remote
cloud sync ~/secrets myencrypted:secrets

docs.text:

cloud schedule-backup ~/documents --interval daily

docs.text:
Restore from backup:

cloud restore backup:documents ~/documents

List available backups:

cloud list-backups

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use encryption for sensitive data
  2. Test restores regularly
  3. Use multiple backends for critical data
  4. Monitor sync status for issues

docs.title: Dotfiles Management
docs.text: Synchronize your configuration files across machines.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Dotfiles are configuration files (usually starting with a dot, like .bashrc) that customize your environment. Machineconfig helps you:

  • Track dotfiles in version control
  • Sync them across machines
  • Handle platform-specific variations

docs.title: Initialize Dotfiles
docs.text: mcfg dotfiles init

docs.title: Sync Dotfiles
docs.text: mcfg dotfiles sync

docs.title: Push Changes
docs.text: mcfg dotfiles push

docs.title: Dotfiles Strategy
docs.text:
Machineconfig uses a flexible approach:

flowchart LR
    A[Git Repository] --> B[Machineconfig]
    B --> C[Symlinks]
    C --> D[~/.config/*]
    C --> E[~/.bashrc]
    C --> F[Other locations]

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Version controlled: Track all changes
  • Portable: Works on any machine
  • Secure: Separate public and private configs
  • Flexible: Override per-machine as needed

docs.title: Public Dotfiles
docs.text:
Configuration that can be shared publicly:

  • Shell aliases
  • Editor settings
  • Tool configurations

docs.title: Private Dotfiles
docs.text:
Sensitive configuration that should stay private:

  • API keys
  • SSH configurations
  • Credentials
# Sync only public
mcfg dotfiles sync --public

# Sync with private
mcfg dotfiles sync --private

docs.title: Platform-Specific Configuration
docs.text:
Machineconfig handles platform differences automatically:

dotfiles/
├── common/           # Shared across all platforms
├── linux/            # Linux-specific
├── macos/            # macOS-specific
└── windows/          # Windows-specific

docs.title: Integration with Cloud Storage
docs.text:
Sync private dotfiles via encrypted cloud storage:

mcfg dotfiles sync --cloud

Supports:

  • OneDrive
  • Google Drive
  • Dropbox
  • Any rclone-supported backend

docs.title: Backup
docs.text:
Create a backup of current dotfiles:

mcfg dotfiles backup

Restore from backup:

mcfg dotfiles restore

docs.title: User Guide Overview
docs.text: Welcome to the Machineconfig User Guide. This guide covers all the features and functionality of machineconfig.

docs.title: What is Machineconfig?
docs.text:
Machineconfig is a comprehensive CLI-based stack manager that helps you:

  • Manage packages across different operating systems
  • Configure systems with consistent settings
  • Sync dotfiles between machines
  • Automate tasks and workflows
  • Handle data backup and synchronization

docs.title: 1. Cross-Platform Consistency
docs.text: Machineconfig provides a unified interface across Windows, macOS, and Linux. Write your configuration once and deploy it anywhere.

docs.title: 2. Stack-Based Approach
docs.text:
Your "stack" includes:

  • CLI tools and packages
  • Configuration files (dotfiles)
  • Secrets and credentials
  • Data and backups
  • Code repositories

docs.title: 3. Modular Architecture
docs.text:
Each component of machineconfig can be used independently:

  • Use just the package manager
  • Use just the dotfiles sync
  • Or use everything together

docs.title: Guide Sections
docs.text: Section Description Package Management Install and manage software Configuration System configuration Dotfiles Manage dotfiles Data Sync Backup and sync data Automation Automate workflows

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
graph TB
    subgraph "Machineconfig"
        A[CLI Interface] --> B[Package Manager]
        A --> C[Config Manager]
        A --> D[Dotfiles Manager]
        A --> E[Data Manager]
        A --> F[Automation]
    end

    B --> G[apt/brew/winget/nix]
    C --> H[System Settings]
    D --> I[Git/Rclone]
    E --> J[Cloud Storage]
    F --> K[Task Scheduler]
